clinical_study.brief_title: Sutures vs. Staples Skin Closure After C-section in Obese Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Staples Compared With Subcuticular Suture for Skin Closure After Cesarean Delivery in Obese Patients

brief_summary.textblock: This is a randomized prospective clinical trial designed to determine the wound complication rates for stainless steel staples versus subcuticular suture for skin closure in the obese parturient (BMI≥ 30kg/m2) undergoing cesarean delivery.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Low enrollment and Pi had no time.

primary_outcome.description: Wound complications will be classified as minor and major and the major complications will be further stratified as Seroma, Hematoma and Wound Infection/Surgical site infection (SSI). Minor wound disruption: any wound disruption that DOES not require that the incision be opened, evacuated, irrigated or debrided. There is no evidence of infection including erythema, induration or purulent material. No antibiotic therapy is given. Major wound disruption requires that incision be opened, evacuated, and or irrigated or debrided and includes: Seroma: collection of serous fluid in the wound without evidence of infection Hematoma: Demonstrable blood clot between the rectus fascia and the skin Infection: Any wound that drains purulent material and shows at least 2 of the classic signs of infection; induration, erythema, tenderness, fever. Wound infections will be further classified as superficial or deep.

secondary_outcome.description: To allow for adequate monitoring and assessment of postoperative pain, standardized postoperative pain analgesia protocol at our institution will be followed. This comprises of non-steroidal anti- inflammatory drugs and Narcotics as needed. Patients will be asked to complete a visual analog pain scale ranging from 0-10 on postoperative day 2. Information on use of pain medication during hospitalization and frequency will also be collected from the medical record.

arm_group.description: Subjects in this group will be randomized to suture for skin closure with computer generated random card draw.
Subjects randomized to skin closure with staples with computer generated random card draw.

intervention.intervention_name: Suture vs. staples closure method after c-section in obese women.
intervention.description: Random card draw to either suture skin closure or staple skin closure arm of study.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- 18 years or older
- BMI ≥ 30kg/m2 on admission to labor and delivery
- Patient is for scheduled cesarean delivery or in non-emergent labor but has an indication for cesarean delivery
- Singleton pregnancies
- Gestational age ≥ 24weeks
- Cesarean delivery performed under regional anesthesia
Exclusion criteria:
- Refusal to participate
- BMI < 30kg/m2
- < 24 weeks gestation
- Intrauterine fetal demise
- Chronic pain syndrome requiring chronic narcotic use
- Emergent clinical situations which preclude obtaining informed consent
